We're going to learn how they designed these awesome visual symbols called coats of arms, and then you'll get to create your very own!

items: Reference images of coats of arms
slides.setup_instructions: Set out art supplies. Look up examples of coats of arms for inspiration. Draw or print a shield outline on your paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so for this project, we need a few things to make our coats of arms look awesome. We'll need some sturdy paper or cardstock so our art doesn't get flimsy, colored pencils or markers to bring our designs to life, a regular pencil for sketching out our ideas, and a ruler to help keep things neat. It's also a good idea to have some examples of real coats of arms handy for inspiration, so maybe have a grown-up help you find some pictures online or print some out.

slides.text: In medieval battles, knights wore full armor including helmets that covered their faces. How could you tell friend from enemy? The answer: heraldry. Each knight carried a unique design on their shield and banner. This system became so important that there were official rules and even 'heralds' — officials who managed and recorded coat of arms designs.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains why coats of arms were so important back in medieval times. Imagine knights all covered up in armor – you wouldn't be able to tell who was who in a big battle! So, they used these special designs on their shields and flags, kind of like a superhero's logo, to show everyone who they were and where they came from.

slides.text: The rules of heraldry: TINCTURES (colors) are divided into metals (gold/yellow called 'Or,' silver/white called 'Argent') and colors (red = Gules, blue = Azure, green = Vert, black = Sable, purple = Purpure). The main rule: never place a color on a color or a metal on a metal — always contrast for visibility.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're learning the secret language of heraldry, starting with colors, called 'tinctures.' There are 'metals' like gold and silver, and then regular 'colors' like red, blue, green, black, and purple. The super important rule here is to always put a metal next to a color, or a color next to a metal – you never want to put color on color or metal on metal, otherwise, it's hard to see, like trying to read black words on a dark blue shirt.

slides.text: CHARGES are the symbols on the shield. Each has meaning: Lion = courage and royalty; Eagle = strength and authority; Horse = readiness; Oak tree = strength and endurance; Star = honor and achievement; Book = learning; Sword = military honor; Cross = faith; Crown = authority; Dove = peace. A shield can be divided into sections (quartered, halved, etc.) with different symbols in each.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to the fun symbols, called 'charges,' that go on the shield! Each symbol has a special meaning, like a lion for courage or a star for honor, so you can pick ones that represent what's important to you. You can even divide your shield into different sections, and put different symbols in each part, which makes the design even more interesting.

slides.text: Plan your personal coat of arms: (1) Choose 2-4 symbols that represent your values, interests, or family. (2) Select your colors following heraldic rules. (3) Decide how to divide your shield. (4) Create a motto — a short phrase that represents your personal philosophy. Famous mottos: 'Semper Fidelis' (Always Faithful), 'Per Ardua ad Astra' (Through Adversity to the Stars).
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to start planning your own coat of arms! Think about what's most important to you – maybe it's bravery, kindness, or being smart – and pick two to four symbols that show those things. Then, choose your colors, remembering the rule about not putting color on color or metal on metal, and think about a short motto, like a personal slogan, that sums up your attitude.

slides.prompt: Design and create your personal coat of arms. Include: a shield divided into at least 2 sections, at least 3 symbolic charges with clear meaning, proper heraldic colors following the metal/color contrast rule, a banner with your personal motto, and on the back of the paper, write an explanation of every symbol and color choice and what it represents about you.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the main event – you get to create your very own coat of arms! Make sure your shield is split into at least two parts, has at least three symbols that mean something to you, and uses colors correctly by contrasting metals and colors. Don't forget to add a banner with your special motto, and on the back, write down exactly what each symbol and color means about you so everyone can understand your story.

slides.text: Heraldry was medieval visual communication — a complete symbolic language. Your coat of arms tells your story in symbols. In an age before most people could read, visual symbols carried enormous power. Many organizations today still use heraldic designs: universities, cities, countries, and military units.
slides.mastery_check: Did the student create a coat of arms following heraldic rules with intentional symbolism and a personal motto?
slides.mascot_explanation: So, your coat of arms is like a secret code that tells your story using pictures and colors, just like people did in medieval times before reading was common. It's pretty cool that even today, places like universities and sports teams still use these kinds of designs to represent themselves. The most important thing is that you've created something that truly shows who you are!

parent_notes: Heraldry combines art, history, and personal identity in an engaging project. Children love choosing symbols that represent them. The design rules (metal on color, never color on color) teach the principle that good design follows rules for practical reasons — visibility in battle. If your child enjoys this, they can design coats of arms for family members or create a family coat of arms together. Connect this to the feudalism content coming in weeks 12-13. Many real-world logos use heraldic principles.
